paragraphs.text: %md # Forest Fire Prediction through KMeans Clustering The United States Forest Service provides datasets that describe forest fires that have occurred in Canada and the United States since year 2000. We can predict where forest fires are prone to occur by partitioning the locations of past burns into clusters whose centroids can be used to optimally place heavy fire fighting equipment as near as possible to where fires are likely to occur. Dataset: https://fsapps.nwcg.gov/gisdata.php

msg.data:
Forest Fire Prediction through KMeans Clustering

The United States Forest Service provides datasets that describe forest fires that have occurred in Canada and the United States since year 2000. We can predict where forest fires are prone to occur by partitioning the locations of past burns into clusters whose centroids can be used to optimally place heavy fire fighting equipment as near as possible to where fires are likely to occur.

Dataset:
https://fsapps.nwcg.gov/gisdata.php

paragraphs.title: Demo Setup Instructions
paragraphs.text:
%md ## Preliminary Setup
Here are all the things that need to be in place for this notebook to run:

Download the MapR Sandbox for Hadoop
Import into VirutalBox
Setup networking for the VM
Increase memory to 8GB.
Start the VM

SSH to the VM

We need a license in order to do snapshots, so here's how to create a license:
Log onto mapr.com/user
Create a new license:
Run this to get the cluster ID:

  maprcli license showid

Run this to get the cluster name:

  maprcli license list

Generate the license then click View Key

Copy and Paste the key to license.txt on the mapr node

Run this command to add the license:
  maprcli license add -license license.txt -is_file true

put user mapr in sudoers

  su
  chmod 640 /etc/sudoers && echo "mapr        ALL=(ALL)       NOPASSWD: ALL" >> /etc/sudoers && chmod 440 /etc/sudoers

Install python dependencies for the notebook:

  sudo yum install python-pip -y
  sudo pip install dbfpy requests pandas bs4 websocket-client

  wget https://github.com/joewalnes/websocketd/releases/download/v0.3.0/websocketd.0.3.0.i386.rpm
  sudo rpm -ivh websocketd.0.3.0.i386.rpm

Copy the following files to /home/mapr/:

```
ml_input_stream.sh
ml_output_stream.sh
mapr-sparkml-streaming-fires-1.0-jar-with-dependencies.jar
```

Download zeppelin. There's not enough disk space in the VM to install zeppelin with all the interpretters, so download this one, which just includes the Spark interpretter:

  wget http://apache.cs.utah.edu/zeppelin/zeppelin-0.8.0/zeppelin-0.8.0-bin-netinst.tgz
  tar -xzvf zeppelin-0.8.0-bin-netinst.tgz
  cd zeppelin-0.8.0-bin-netinst/

Install the markdown interpretter:
   
   ./bin/install-interpreter.sh --name md

Install the shell interpretter:
   ./bin/install-interpreter.sh --name shell 

Add this to the artiface dependencies in the zeppelin config screen:

  org.apache.zeppelin:zeppelin-shell:0.8.0

  or whatever is output by this command:
    grep shell conf/interpreter-list | awk '{print $2}'

Install the angular interpretter:
  ./bin/install-interpreter.sh --name angular

  For some reason, this new interpretter won't show up in zeppelin's interpretter config screen, so go to that screen, click the create button, secify "angular" as the interpretter name and interpreter group, then put this as the artifact and click save and restart:
 
    org.apache.zeppelin:zeppelin-angular:0.8.0
  
  or whatever is output by this command:
    grep angular conf/interpreter-list | awk '{print $2}'

Setup Spark home property:

  echo "export SPARK_HOME=/opt/mapr/spark/spark-2.2.1/" >> conf/zeppelin-env.sh

Start Zeppelin
  bin/zeppelin-daemon.sh start

open http://10.0.0.101:8080

Then open your notebook that uses angular, click the gear icon in the top right, and attach the angular interpretter to the notebook and click save.

Do the same for the markdown (md) interpretter.

Add classpath to shell interetter config:
"groupArtifactVersion": "org.apache.zeppelin:zeppelin-shell:0.8.0",

paragraphs.title: Convert shapefiles to CSVs
paragraphs.text:
%python
import csv
from dbfpy import dbf
import os
import sys
DATADIR='/mapr/demo.mapr.com/user/mapr/data/fires/'

for filename in os.listdir(DATADIR):

    if filename.endswith('.dbf'):
        print "Converting %s to csv" % filename
        csv_fn = DATADIR+filename[:-4]+ ".csv"
        with open(csv_fn,'wb') as csvfile:
            in_db = dbf.Dbf(DATADIR+filename)
            out_csv = csv.writer(csvfile)
            names = []
            for field in in_db.header.fields:
                names.append(field.name)
            out_csv.writerow(names)
            for rec in in_db:
                out_csv.writerow(rec.fieldData)
            in_db.close()
            print "Done..."

paragraphs.title: Define schema for datasets since 2009
paragraphs.text:
import sqlContext.implicits._
import sqlContext._
val modis_schema = StructType(Array(
  StructField("area", DoubleType, true),
  StructField("perimeter", DoubleType, true),
  StructField("firenum", IntegerType, true),      
  StructField("fire_id", IntegerType, true),      
  StructField("latitude", DoubleType, true),
  StructField("longitude", DoubleType, true),
  StructField("date", TimestampType, true),
  StructField("julian", IntegerType, true),
  StructField("gmt", IntegerType, true),
  StructField("temp", DoubleType, true),     
  StructField("spix", DoubleType, true),      
  StructField("tpix", DoubleType, true),            
  StructField("src", StringType, true),
  StructField("sat_src", StringType, true),      
  StructField("conf", IntegerType, true),
  StructField("frp", DoubleType, true)
))

paragraphs.title: Train the KMeans model for 100 clusters
paragraphs.text:
val featureCols = Array("latitude", "longitude")
val assembler = new VectorAssembler().setInputCols(featureCols).setOutputCol("features")
val df2 = assembler.transform(df)
val Array(trainingData, testData) = df2.randomSplit(Array(0.7, 0.3), 5043)

val kmeans = new KMeans().setK(100).setFeaturesCol("features").setMaxIter(4)
val model = kmeans.fit(trainingData)
println("Final Centers: ")
model.clusterCenters.foreach(println)

paragraphs.title: Save the Model
paragraphs.text:
// Saved the k-means model to a file so it can be accessed later without creating it again from scratch:
model.write.overwrite().save("/mapr/demo.mapr.com/user/mapr/data/save_fire_model-cascadia")

paragraphs.title: Load the Model (optional)
paragraphs.text:
// If you've previously saved the model file, then you can load it like this:
val model = KMeansModel.load("/mapr/demo.mapr.com/user/mapr/data/save_fire_model-cascadia")

msg.data: model: org.apache.spark.ml.clustering.KMeansModel = kmeans_67039e04715f

paragraphs.title: Setup Map (save centroids)
paragraphs.text: z.angularBind("centroid", model.clusterCenters)

paragraphs.title: Setup Map (initialize angular)
Where would you stage firefighting equipment?

paragraphs.text:
%md # Operationalizing the model
***Which staging area should respond when a new forest fire starts?***
We can use our previously saved model to answer that question. The following section shows how the model we built above can be used to answer that question and how it can be applied to a live feed of newly detected fires for rapid fire response.

msg.data:
Operationalizing the model

Which staging area should respond when a new forest fire starts?
We can use our previously saved model to answer that question. The following section shows how the model we built above can be used to answer that question and how it can be applied to a live feed of newly detected fires for rapid fire response.

paragraphs.title: Which fire station (centroid) should respond to a new fire?
paragraphs.text:
val featureCols = Array("lat", "lon")
val assembler = new VectorAssembler().setInputCols(featureCols).setOutputCol("features")
val fire_location = Seq((42.3,-112.2 )).toDF("lat", "lon")
val df3 = assembler.transform(fire_location)
val categories = model.transform(df3)
val centroid_id = categories.select("prediction").rdd.map(r => r(0)).collect()(0).asInstanceOf[Int]
val centroid_coordinate = model.clusterCenters(centroid_id)

df3: org.apache.spark.sql.DataFrame = [lat: double, lon: double ... 1 more field]
categories: org.apache.spark.sql.DataFrame = [lat: double, lon: double ... 2 more fields]

centroid_coordinate: org.apache.spark.ml.linalg.Vector = [42.15340495867765,-112.40152341597808]

paragraphs.text: println("%html <h1>Notify fire station #" + centroid_id + " at location " + centroid_coordinate)

%md Now that we can identify which fire station should respond to a fire, 
lets identify which fire stations should respond to all the currently active fires posted by USFS.

paragraphs.title: Initialize web scraper
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark 
import requests
import pandas as pd
from bs4 import BeautifulSoup

class HTMLTableParser:   
    def parse_url(self, url):
        response = requests.get(url)
        soup = BeautifulSoup(response.text, 'lxml')
        return [(table,self.parse_html_table(table))\
                for table in soup.find_all('table')]  
    def parse_html_table(self, table):
        n_columns = 0
        n_rows=0
        column_names = []
        # Find number of rows and columns
        # we also find the column titles if we can
        for row in table.find_all('tr'):            
            # Determine the number of rows in the table
            td_tags = row.find_all('td')
            if len(td_tags) > 0:
                n_rows+=1
                if n_columns == 0:
                    # Set the number of columns for our table
                    n_columns = len(td_tags)
            # Handle column names if we find them
            th_tags = row.find_all('th') 
            if len(th_tags) > 0 and len(column_names) == 0:
                for th in th_tags:
                    column_names.append(th.get_text())
        # Safeguard on Column Titles
        if len(column_names) > 0 and len(column_names) != n_columns:
            raise Exception("Column titles do not match the number of columns")
        columns = column_names if len(column_names) > 0 else range(0,n_columns)
        df = pd.DataFrame(columns = columns,
                          index= range(0,n_rows))
        row_marker = 0
        for row in table.find_all('tr'):
            column_marker = 0
            columns = row.find_all('td')
            for column in columns:
                df.iat[row_marker,column_marker] = column.get_text()
                column_marker += 1
            if len(columns) > 0:
                row_marker += 1
        # Convert to float if possible
        for col in df:
            try:
                df[col] = df[col].astype(float)
            except ValueError:
                pass 
        return df

paragraphs.title: Scrape real-time fire detections from web
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark 
url="https://fsapps.nwcg.gov/afm/current.php?op=table&sensor=modis"
hp = HTMLTableParser()
df = hp.parse_url(url)[4][1] 
# rename the columns according to what's in the first row
df.columns = df.iloc[0]
df = df.reindex(df.index.drop(0))
spark_df = sqlContext.createDataFrame(df)
spark_df.registerTempTable("active_fires") # Save as table
spark_df.printSchema()

root

 |-- Time (GMT): string (nullable = true)

 |-- Latitude(WGS84): string (nullable = true)
 |-- Agency: string (nullable = true)
 |-- Admin Unit: string (nullable = true)
 |-- Land Cover: string (nullable = true)
 |-- Fire Danger: string (nullable = true)
 |-- County: string (nullable = true)
 |-- State: string (nullable = true)
 |-- Nearest Town: string (nullable = true)
 |-- Distance to Town(mi): string (nullable = true)

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark print("%html

There are " + str(len(df.index)) + " fires currently active.

")

msg.data: There are 99 fires currently active.

paragraphs.title: Active Fires by State
paragraphs.text:
%sql 
select count(`Land Cover`), state from active_fires  where `state` not like '%STATE%' group by state order by count(`Land Cover`) desc limit 8

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.title: Cumulative Fire Danger
paragraphs.text:
%sql
select `Fire Danger`, `Land Cover` from active_fires where `Fire Danger` not like '%N-A%'

paragraphs.title: Initialize streams
paragraphs.text:
%sh
# start streams
maprcli stream create -path /user/mapr/ml_input -produceperm p -consumeperm p -topicperm p -ttl 604800
maprcli stream topic create -path /user/mapr/ml_input -topic requester001
# ttl 604800 is 1 week
maprcli stream create -path /user/mapr/ml_output -produceperm p -consumeperm p -topicperm p -ttl 604800
maprcli stream topic create -path /user/mapr/ml_output -topic kmeans001

paragraphs.title: Start the Spark Streaming notification task
paragraphs.text:
%sh 
# run this in a terminal - doesn't work well in Zeppelin because it ties up the spark context while listening on the stream
/opt/mapr/spark/spark-2.3.1/bin/spark-submit --class com.sparkkafka.fire.SparkKafkaConsumerProducer --master local[2] /root/mapr-sparkml-streaming-fires-1.0-jar-with-dependencies.jar /mapr/demo.mapr.com/user/mapr/data/save_fire_model-cascadia  /user/mapr/ml_input:requester001 /user/mapr/ml_output:kmeans001

msg.data: Warning: Unable to determine $DRILL_HOME

paragraphs.title: Start websocket interface for streams
paragraphs.text:
%sh
# run this in a terminal - doesn't work well in Zeppelin
websocketd --port=3433 --dir=. --devconsole &

paragraphs.title: Identify which fire stations (centroids) should respond to active fires
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark 
import websocket
websocket.enableTrace(False)
ws = websocket.create_connection("ws://localhost:3433/ml_input_stream.sh")
for index, row in df.iterrows():
    ws.send(row['Latitude(WGS84)']+","+row['Longitude(WGS84)'])
    print(row['Latitude(WGS84)']+","+row['Longitude(WGS84)'])
    ws.recv()
ws.close()

%md 
### Click [here](http://10.0.0.101:3433/ml_input_stream.sh) to watch the fire notifications stream (ML input).

msg.data: Click here to watch the fire notifications stream (ML input).

paragraphs.text:
%md 
### Click [here](http://10.0.0.101:3433/ml_output_stream.sh) to watch the fire station alert stream (ML output).

msg.data: Click here to watch the fire station alert stream (ML output).

paragraphs.title: Backup training data and model files
paragraphs.text:
%sh
maprcli volume snapshot remove -volume mapr_home -snapshotname USFS_Experiment 
maprcli volume snapshot create -cluster my.cluster.com -snapshotname USFS_Experiment -volume users
ls -la /mapr/my.cluster.com/user/mapr/.snapshot/
